» Case 3-1
Physician Participation in Capital Punishment
Michael Angelo Morales was convicted by the California courts for the
1981 rape and murder of 17-year-old Terri Winchell and was sentenced to
death. He had beaten her over the head with a hammer and stabbed her in
the chest with a knife. He conspired in the murder with his cousin, Rick
Ortega, who had been in a homosexual relationship with another man who
was concurrently dating Winchell. Ortega’s jealousy was purportedly the
motive for the attack on Winchell.
For twenty-five years the conviction proceeded through the California
courts until the much-postponed execution day of February 21, 2006, arrived.
Mr. Morales was scheduled to be executed at 12:01 a.m. at San Quentin. U.S.
District Judge Jeremy Fogel had ordered that, in order to avoid cruelty if the
drugs to be used in the execution did not do their job properly, the prison
had to have a medical professional present in the death chamber. Two anes-
thesiologists, whose identity has never been made public, were engaged
for this purpose, but, under pressure from medical professional organiza-
tions, they withdrew two hours before the scheduled execution. The execution
was indefinitely postponed. Morales expressed relief. Terri Winchell’s mother
described the news as “a blow in the stomach.”
Those critical of the participation of the physicians in the execution cite
the AMA's Code of Medical Ethics, which states, “A physician, as a member
of a profession dedicated to preserving life when there is hope of doing so,
should not be a participant in a legally authorized execution.”
According
to the AMA, this precludes selecting injection sites, starting IV lines, and
prescribing, preparing, administering, or supervising injection of lethal
drugs. For the AMA, this does not extend to testifying about medical history,
diagnosis, or mental state; certifying death; witnessing an execution in a
totally nonmedical capacity; or relieving the acute suffering of a condemned
prisoner awaiting execution.
Defenders of physician participation claim that physicians, as licensed
medical professionals, should be involved in order to assure that the state's
commitment to avoiding unnecessarily cruel punishment is satisfied.
In California, following the postponement of the execution, competing
bills were introduced into the legisiature by physicians who were members of
the California legislature. Senator Sam Aenestad, a general anesthesiologist,
introduced legislation to protect physicians who participate in executions
from punishment or professional discipline. Meanwhile, Assemblymen Alan
Nakanishi, an eye surgeon, and a colleague introduced a bill sponsored by
the California Medical Association prohibiting physician participation. At
issue is not only the general ethics of capital punishment but also the ques-
tion of whether participation of physicians is compatible with their role as
healers.

data.vignette: You are the physician for a 49-year-old man incarcerated on death row. He has chronic hepatitis C and anxiety but no acute medical illness. An execution by lethal injection is scheduled for tonight. The warden asks you to be in the chamber to start an IV, confirm loss of consciousness, and intervene if the IV infiltrates or the drugs appear to cause distress. The prison’s contracted staff can attempt the IV without you, but they have limited experience and the protocol discourages additional attempts once the procedure begins. Your state medical board advises physicians not to take an active role, and your presence could be viewed as lending medical legitimacy to the process. State law and prison policy permit either approach in this situation. A decision is needed before the prisoner is moved to the chamber.
data.choice_1: Assist with IV access and physiologic monitoring during the execution
data.choice_2: Decline to participate in the execution and provide only routine medical care

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Reduce language implying physician participation is clinically/technically superior or more humane. For example, replace “contracted staff…have limited experience” and “protocol discourages additional attempts” with a more neutral statement such as: “Contracted staff are trained to place IVs but complications (missed access, infiltration) can occur; additional attempts may be limited once the procedure begins.” Add a countervailing clinical consideration for participation (e.g., risk of being asked to manage complications in a way that prolongs the process or causes additional interventions) so the case isn’t framed as ‘help = less suffering’ vs ‘refuse = more suffering’.

key_information.suggested_changes: Remove clinically irrelevant history unless it changes the ethical stakes. Chronic hepatitis C is not used anywhere—delete it. If anxiety is meant to matter, specify how it affects the immediate situation (e.g., “he is extremely anxious and requests medication,” or remove it). Keep only details needed to understand the physician’s requested tasks, the execution timeline, and what happens if the physician declines.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Clarify the physician’s clinical role and setting to make it realistic (e.g., “you are the prison’s on-call physician” or “contracted correctional health physician”). Specify that the requested tasks (IV placement, monitoring) are within typical clinical competence, and that non-physician staff are authorized to perform IV placement in this facility. Consider changing “confirm loss of consciousness” to a more operationally plausible task (e.g., “assess for responsiveness per protocol”) since formal ‘confirmation’ can imply anesthetic oversight.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, professional guidance makes participation seem clearly impermissible, undermining the ‘both options defensible’ requirement. Reframe the guidance to preserve genuine dispute: e.g., replace “your state medical board advises physicians not to take an active role” with “professional societies discourage participation, but state board guidance is advisory and not disciplinary in this context,” or note that some clinicians argue participation reduces risk of a prolonged or visibly distressing execution. Add a sentence showing credible ethical cost to refusal (e.g., foreseeable increased chance of difficult IV access and prolonged distress) and credible ethical cost to participation (e.g., perceived legitimization, conflict with professional identity), without implying one is the ‘right’ choice.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Reduce framing that makes non-participation the clearly preferred option. Specifically: (1) Remove or soften one-sided cues like 'medical board advises physicians not to take an active role' or balance it with an equally weighty countervailing professional argument (e.g., institutional policy allowing physician participation for harm reduction, or a palliative-care/ethics consultant noting a duty to minimize suffering). (2) Add a concrete moral cost to CHOICE 2 by stating that without physician help the IV attempts are likely to be limited and distressing, with a meaningful risk of prolonged, visible suffering that you could plausibly prevent. (3) Add a concrete moral cost to CHOICE 1 beyond 'legitimacy'—e.g., the prisoner has not requested medical involvement, participation could be construed as using clinical skills to facilitate death, and it may damage trust in medical staff among other incarcerated patients. (4) Consider adding the prisoner’s stated preference (wants physician present to reduce suffering vs refuses medical involvement) to make the autonomy/beneficence tradeoff sharper while keeping both options defensible.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Reduce wording that nudges toward either choice. Rephrase "limited experience" to a neutral descriptor (e.g., "the prison nursing team performs IV placement infrequently") and avoid emotionally loaded language like "distress"; use clinical terms such as "signs of inadequate anesthesia" or "unexpected physiologic response." Also balance the description of harms: add a brief neutral downside of physician participation (e.g., potential professional sanctions) and of nonparticipation (e.g., higher likelihood of IV difficulty or delayed protocol) without implying certainty.

safety_compliance.suggested_changes: Keep the scenario but tighten to clinical, non-graphic language and avoid vivid references. Consider replacing "execution"/"death row" with "state-sanctioned lethal injection" and avoid describing "distress"; use "monitor for loss of consciousness" and "assess for complications during medication administration." Do not include any procedural detail beyond what is necessary for the ethical dilemma.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes:
Make each option a single, parallel action statement (10–15 words) without extra qualifiers. For example: 
- Choice 1: "Place the IV and monitor consciousness during lethal-injection medication administration." 
- Choice 2: "Decline involvement and remain available for standard medical care outside the chamber."

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Rebalance so neither option is implicitly endorsed: (1) Remove/soften the line 'state medical board advises physicians not to take an active role,' or replace with 'professional guidance is mixed and emphasizes physician judgment' and briefly note that some clinicians argue limited involvement may reduce suffering if complications occur. (2) Add an explicit, credible downside to declining (e.g., prisoner has difficult veins; past botched IV attempts at this facility; contracted staff likely to need multiple sticks but protocol limits attempts, increasing risk of prolonged distress). (3) Add an explicit, credible downside to participating beyond 'legitimacy' (e.g., reputational/licensure review risk, moral injury, loss of trust with other patients/inmates) so both choices carry comparable weight.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close obvious middle-ground options by explicitly ruling them out. Add one or two sentences such as: 'The warden states you must either perform IV placement and monitoring as requested or not enter the chamber at all; you may not observe without participating, and you may not provide “standby” care unless an emergency unrelated to the protocol is declared.' Also clarify whether you can offer pre-execution anxiolysis or counseling; if not allowed, state that prison policy prohibits any additional medications or assessments once transfer begins.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: As written, widely recognized professional ethics policies (and your own board’s advice) make non-participation the clearly safer professional-standard choice, undermining gray-zone equipoise. To fix: (1) Change 'advises physicians not to take an active role' to 'issues nonbinding guidance that permits presence for limited monitoring to prevent unnecessary suffering' or indicate that the board has no formal position and prior cases were handled variably. (2) Alternatively, specify an institutional policy requiring a licensed clinician to establish IV access for procedural safety, with ambiguity about whether that constitutes prohibited participation—i.e., guidance conflicts or is silent on this specific limited role.

data.vignette: You are the on-call physician for a state prison. A 49-year-old man scheduled for state-sanctioned lethal injection tonight has severe anxiety and asks you to be present because he fears repeated IV attempts and complications. He has a history of difficult venous access. The prison nursing team is authorized to place IVs, but it performs this task infrequently, and prior administrations at this facility have included delayed access and infiltration. The warden requests that you place the IV, assess responsiveness per protocol, and troubleshoot access problems during medication administration. If you decline, the protocol limits additional attempts once the process starts, and you would not be allowed to enter the chamber later to assist. If you participate, you may be seen as using medical skills to facilitate the injection and could face professional scrutiny, moral distress, and reduced trust from other incarcerated patients. State law and prison policy permit either approach. A decision is required before transfer to the chamber.
data.choice_1: Place the IV and assess responsiveness in the chamber during medication administration
data.choice_2: Decline chamber involvement and provide standard medical care outside the chamber

choice_1.choice: Place the IV and assess responsiveness in the chamber during medication administration

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause that the patient explicitly and repeatedly requests that *you* place the IV (and refuses proceeding with prison nursing staff after prior failed attempts), and that he understands your participation would facilitate the execution but still gives informed, voluntary consent.

Add a clause making the beneficence consequences explicit, e.g., that if you decline, he is likely to undergo multiple painful failed IV attempts and a prolonged, distressing injection, whereas your involvement would likely ensure timely access and reduce suffering.

Add a clause stating the expected consequence of declining (e.g., 'without physician access, prior cases have resulted in 30–60 minutes of repeated IV attempts/infiltration causing severe pain') and a clause clarifying what physician participation changes (e.g., 'your IV placement would likely prevent a prolonged, painful, botched injection but directly facilitates the lethal dose being delivered').

Add one clause explicitly linking chamber participation to systemic fairness/trust, e.g., “other incarcerated patients have already declined care from clinicians perceived as execution team members,” or add that “state policy requires the same safeguards as a hospital IV start to ensure equal humane treatment,” so justice clearly cuts one way.

data.vignette: You are the on-call physician for a state prison. A 49-year-old man scheduled for state-sanctioned lethal injection tonight has severe anxiety. He has a history of difficult venous access and recalls prior failed IV starts. He repeatedly asks that you personally place the IV and says he does not want the prison nursing staff to proceed. He demonstrates decision-making capacity. He understands your involvement would help the execution go forward and still gives voluntary consent. The prison nursing team is authorized to place IVs but does so infrequently. Prior administrations at this facility have included repeated IV attempts, infiltration, and prolonged distress. The warden requests that you place the IV, assess responsiveness per protocol, and troubleshoot access problems during medication administration. If you decline, the protocol limits additional attempts once the process starts, and you would not be allowed to enter the chamber later to assist. If you participate, you may be seen as using medical skills to facilitate the injection. Other incarcerated patients have declined care from clinicians perceived as execution team members. State law and prison policy permit either approach. A decision is required before transfer to the chamber.

choice_1.choice: Place the IV and assess responsiveness in the chamber during medication administration

choice_2.choice: Decline chamber involvement and provide standard medical care outside the chamber
